metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the motion of projectiles near Earth's surface, including a qualitative description of the effects of air resistance

projectile_definition.name: Projectile Definition
projectile_definition.correct: A projectile is an object that has been launched or dropped and moves freely under the influence of gravity alone (when air resistance is ignored).

any moving object.error: Projectiles specifically have no propulsion after launch.
any moving object.fix: A rocket with engines running is not a projectile. A ball after leaving your hand is.
any moving object.action: Ask: does the object have any force besides gravity acting on it after launch?

only objects thrown upward.error: Dropped objects and horizontal launches are also projectiles.
only objects thrown upward.fix: Any object moving freely under gravity is a projectile, regardless of launch angle.
only objects thrown upward.action: List examples: dropped ball, kicked football, thrown javelin—all projectiles.

objects moving in a straight line.fix: Gravity curves the path. Only if launched straight up/down is the path straight.
objects moving in a straight line.action: Draw the path of a thrown ball. It curves—that's projectile motion.

objects with constant velocity.error: Projectiles accelerate vertically due to gravity.
objects with constant velocity.fix: Velocity changes because of gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s² down).
objects with constant velocity.action: The vertical velocity changes constantly. Only horizontal velocity is constant.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what defines a projectile.
persistent.action: Key features: launched/dropped, no propulsion after launch, only gravity acts (ignoring air).

independence_of_motion.name: Independence of Horizontal and Vertical Motion
independence_of_motion.formula: Horizontal and vertical motion are independent
independence_of_motion.correct: The horizontal and vertical components of projectile motion are completely independent. Only time links them.

horizontal affects vertical.error: Horizontal velocity does not affect vertical motion.
horizontal affects vertical.fix: A ball dropped and a ball thrown horizontally hit ground at same time.
horizontal affects vertical.action: Classic demo: drop one ball, throw another horizontally. They land together.

vertical affects horizontal.error: Vertical motion does not affect horizontal velocity.
vertical affects horizontal.fix: The horizontal velocity stays constant regardless of vertical motion.
vertical affects horizontal.action: Horizontal velocity at launch = horizontal velocity at landing (no air resistance).

they must be added together.error: Analyse them separately, then combine final velocities if needed.
they must be added together.fix: Solve horizontal and vertical independently. Use time to connect them.
they must be added together.action: Step 1: solve vertical. Step 2: solve horizontal. Step 3: combine if needed.

acceleration affects both.error: Gravitational acceleration only affects vertical motion.
acceleration affects both.fix: a = 9.8 m/s² down affects only v_y. No acceleration horizontally.
acceleration affects both.action: Horizontal: a_x = 0. Vertical: a_y = 9.8 m/s² down.

persistent.gap: You're not treating horizontal and vertical motion separately.
persistent.action: Golden rule: solve each direction independently. Time is the only link.

vertical_acceleration.name: Vertical Acceleration
vertical_acceleration.correct: All projectiles near Earth's surface have constant vertical acceleration of 9.8 m/s² downward, regardless of mass or horizontal velocity.

acceleration depends on mass.error: All objects fall at the same rate (ignoring air resistance).
acceleration depends on mass.fix: Galileo showed: heavy and light objects have same acceleration.
acceleration depends on mass.action: Drop a book and a piece of paper together in vacuum—same acceleration.

acceleration is zero at peak.error: Acceleration is constant (9.8 m/s² down) even at the peak.
acceleration is zero at peak.fix: Velocity is zero at peak, not acceleration. Force of gravity never stops.
acceleration is zero at peak.action: At peak: v = 0, but a = 9.8 m/s² down. Velocity and acceleration are different.

acceleration changes during flight.error: Near Earth's surface, g is constant throughout flight.
acceleration changes during flight.fix: For typical projectiles, g doesn't vary enough to matter.
acceleration changes during flight.action: g only varies significantly at very high altitudes (hundreds of km).

heavier objects have more acceleration.error: Mass cancels out: F = mg, a = F/m = g.
heavier objects have more acceleration.fix: More mass means more gravitational force, but also more inertia. Cancels out.
heavier objects have more acceleration.action: Write: a = F/m = mg/m = g. Mass cancels.

persistent.action: Memorise: a = g = 9.8 m/s² down, always, for all projectiles near Earth.

horizontal_velocity.name: Constant Horizontal Velocity
horizontal_velocity.correct: With no air resistance, horizontal velocity remains constant throughout flight because there is no horizontal force.

horizontal velocity decreases.error: Without air resistance, nothing slows horizontal motion.
horizontal velocity decreases.fix: No horizontal force → no horizontal acceleration → constant v_x.
horizontal velocity decreases.action: Newton's 1st law: no force = no change in velocity.

horizontal velocity becomes zero.error: Horizontal velocity never changes (without air resistance).
horizontal velocity becomes zero.fix: Only vertical velocity can become zero (at peak). Horizontal stays constant.
horizontal velocity becomes zero.action: At peak of flight, v_x is still the same as at launch.

gravity affects horizontal velocity.fix: Gravity pulls down, not sideways. It only affects v_y.
gravity affects horizontal velocity.action: Draw force diagram: gravity arrow points down. No horizontal component.

horizontal velocity increases.error: No force means no acceleration in that direction.
horizontal velocity increases.fix: Horizontal speed stays exactly what it was at launch.
horizontal velocity increases.action: If launched at v_x = 10 m/s, it lands at v_x = 10 m/s.

persistent.gap: You think horizontal velocity changes during projectile motion.
persistent.action: No horizontal force → no horizontal acceleration → v_x stays constant.

velocity_components.name: Resolving Velocity into Components
velocity_components.formula: v_x = v cos θ, v_y = v sin θ
velocity_components.correct: Initial velocity is resolved into horizontal (v cos θ) and vertical (v sin θ) components, where θ is the angle above horizontal.

v_x = v sin θ.error: Sine gives vertical, cosine gives horizontal.
v_x = v sin θ.fix: Adjacent = cos, Opposite = sin. Horizontal is adjacent to angle.
v_x = v sin θ.action: Draw right triangle. Horizontal is adjacent to θ → use cosine.

v_y = v cos θ.error: Cosine gives horizontal, sine gives vertical.
v_y = v cos θ.fix: Vertical is opposite to the angle → use sine.

v_x = v/cos θ.fix: v_x = v × cos θ. Components are smaller than the total.
v_x = v/cos θ.action: Components must be ≤ total velocity. Division would make them larger.

v_y = v/sin θ.fix: v_y = v × sin θ. The total velocity is the hypotenuse.
v_y = v/sin θ.action: v is the hypotenuse. Components are the legs, which are smaller.

persistent.gap: You're confusing sine and cosine when resolving vectors.
persistent.action: Memorise: Horizontal = v cos θ (adjacent), Vertical = v sin θ (opposite).

maximum_height.name: Maximum Height
maximum_height.correct: At maximum height, vertical velocity is zero (v_y = 0). The projectile is momentarily stationary in the vertical direction only.

velocity is zero at max height.error: Only VERTICAL velocity is zero. Horizontal velocity continues.
velocity is zero at max height.fix: v_y = 0 at peak, but v_x is still whatever it was at launch.
velocity is zero at max height.action: At peak: v_y = 0, v_x ≠ 0 (unless launched straight up).

acceleration is zero at max height.error: Acceleration is still 9.8 m/s² down at the peak.
acceleration is zero at max height.fix: Gravity doesn't stop. The ball is still being pulled down.
acceleration is zero at max height.action: If a = 0 at peak, what would make the ball come back down?

projectile stops at max height.error: Horizontal motion continues. Only vertical motion pauses.
projectile stops at max height.fix: The projectile keeps moving horizontally while at peak height.
projectile stops at max height.action: Watch a ball at peak—it's still moving forward, just not up or down.

max height occurs at end of flight.error: Max height is at the midpoint (for symmetric launches).
max height occurs at end of flight.fix: For a projectile returning to same height, max height is at t/2.
max height occurs at end of flight.action: Time to peak = time from peak to ground (symmetric flight).

persistent.gap: You're confusing what happens at maximum height.
persistent.action: At peak: v_y = 0 (vertical stops), v_x = constant (horizontal continues), a = g (never stops).

time_of_flight.name: Time of Flight
time_of_flight.formula: Time links horizontal and vertical motion
time_of_flight.correct: The time a projectile is in the air is determined by vertical motion. This same time applies to horizontal calculations.

horizontal distance determines time.error: Time is determined by vertical motion, not horizontal.
horizontal distance determines time.fix: Calculate time from vertical equations, then use it horizontally.
horizontal distance determines time.action: Step 1: Find t from vertical. Step 2: Use t in s_x = v_x × t.

time depends on horizontal speed.error: A faster horizontal throw doesn't stay up longer.
time depends on horizontal speed.fix: Vertical motion alone determines flight time.
time depends on horizontal speed.action: Throw horizontally at 1 m/s or 100 m/s—same time to hit ground.

time is different for each direction.error: Time is the SAME for both horizontal and vertical motion.
time is different for each direction.fix: Time is the link between the two independent motions.
time is different for each direction.action: The projectile experiences both motions simultaneously for the same duration.

faster projectiles stay up longer.error: Only vertical velocity component affects time of flight.
faster projectiles stay up longer.fix: A higher launch angle (more v_y) gives longer flight time.
faster projectiles stay up longer.action: Compare: throw hard horizontally vs lob gently upward. Lob stays up longer.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how time connects the two motions.
persistent.action: Time is determined by vertical motion. Use that same time for horizontal calculations.

range_formula.name: Range of a Projectile
range_formula.formula: R = v_x × t, or R = (u² sin 2θ)/g
range_formula.correct: Range is the horizontal distance traveled. It equals horizontal velocity times total flight time.

range = v × t.error: Use horizontal velocity only, not total velocity.
range = v × t.fix: Range = v_x × t, where v_x is the horizontal component.
range = v × t.action: The vertical velocity doesn't contribute to horizontal distance.

range depends on mass.error: Mass doesn't appear in range calculations (ignoring air).
range depends on mass.fix: R = v_x × t. No mass term anywhere.
range depends on mass.action: A heavy ball and light ball with same v and θ have same range (no air).

maximum range at 90°.error: 90° is straight up—zero horizontal velocity, zero range.
maximum range at 90°.fix: Maximum range is at 45° for launches returning to same height.

range increases with angle always.fix: Complementary angles (30° and 60°) give equal range.
range increases with angle always.action: Graph range vs angle: peaks at 45°, symmetric around it.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what determines projectile range.
persistent.action: Range = v_x × t. More horizontal speed OR more time → more range.

symmetry_of_flight.name: Symmetry of Projectile Motion
symmetry_of_flight.correct: For a projectile returning to its launch height, the motion is symmetric: time up equals time down, and launch speed equals landing speed.

takes longer to go up.error: Time up = time down (for same height).
takes longer to go up.fix: Symmetry: what goes up must come down at the same rate.
takes longer to go up.action: Time to peak = total time ÷ 2 (for symmetric flight).

lands faster than launched.error: Speed at landing = speed at launch (same height, no air).
lands faster than launched.fix: Energy conservation: same height means same speed.
lands faster than launched.action: KE + PE is conserved. Same height = same PE = same KE = same speed.

lands slower than launched.error: Without air resistance, no energy is lost.
lands slower than launched.fix: Landing speed = launch speed (at same height).
lands slower than launched.action: The vertical velocity at landing = negative of vertical velocity at launch.

path is different going down.error: The path is symmetric (parabola) about the peak.
path is different going down.fix: Trace the path up, then mirror it going down.
path is different going down.action: Draw the parabola—it's symmetric about the vertical line through the peak.

persistent.gap: You don't recognize the symmetry of ideal projectile motion.
persistent.action: For same launch/landing height: t_up = t_down, v_launch = v_land, path is symmetric.

kinematic_equations.name: Kinematic Equations for Projectiles
kinematic_equations.formula: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², v² = u² + 2as
kinematic_equations.correct: The constant acceleration equations apply to vertical projectile motion, with a = g = 9.8 m/s² downward.

equations don't apply to projectiles.error: Projectile motion IS constant acceleration motion (vertically).
equations don't apply to projectiles.fix: a = g = constant, so kinematic equations work perfectly.
equations don't apply to projectiles.action: All 5 kinematic equations apply to vertical motion.

use the equations horizontally with a =.fix: Use kinematic equations vertically (a = g). Use s = vt horizontally (a = 0).
use the equations horizontally with a =.action: Vertical: full kinematic equations. Horizontal: just s = v × t.

a = 0 vertically.fix: Gravity acts vertically, giving constant vertical acceleration.
a = 0 vertically.action: Don't confuse horizontal (a = 0) with vertical (a = g).

different equations for up vs down.error: Same equations throughout, just be consistent with sign convention.
different equations for up vs down.fix: Choose up = positive or down = positive and stick with it.
different equations for up vs down.action: If up is positive: u_y > 0 at launch, a = −9.8 m/s².

persistent.gap: You're not applying kinematic equations correctly to projectiles.
persistent.action: Vertical: use kinematic equations with a = ±9.8 m/s². Horizontal: use s = vt (a = 0).

air_resistance_effects.name: Effects of Air Resistance
air_resistance_effects.formula: Qualitative: reduces height, range, and speed
air_resistance_effects.correct: Air resistance opposes motion, causing reduced maximum height, reduced range, slower speeds, and an asymmetric trajectory.

air resistance only affects vertical.error: Air resistance opposes motion in ALL directions.
air resistance only affects vertical.fix: Both horizontal and vertical velocities are reduced by air resistance.
air resistance only affects vertical.action: Horizontal: v_x decreases. Vertical: going up slowed more, coming down slower.

air resistance only affects horizontal.error: Air resistance acts in both directions.
air resistance only affects horizontal.fix: Going up: air + gravity both oppose. Coming down: air opposes, gravity helps.
air resistance only affects horizontal.action: Vertical motion is also affected—max height is reduced.

trajectory stays symmetric.error: With air resistance, trajectory becomes asymmetric.
trajectory stays symmetric.fix: The projectile falls steeper than it rose.
trajectory stays symmetric.action: Draw: with air, the descent is steeper, landing closer to launch point.

range increases with air resistance.error: Range decreases because both speeds are reduced.
range increases with air resistance.fix: Less horizontal velocity + less time = much less range.
range increases with air resistance.action: Compare a smooth ball vs a rough ball—smooth goes farther.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how air resistance affects projectile motion.
persistent.action: Air resistance opposes motion: reduced v_x, reduced v_y, less height, less range, asymmetric path.

asymmetric_trajectory.name: Asymmetric Trajectory with Air Resistance
asymmetric_trajectory.correct: With air resistance, the trajectory is asymmetric: the projectile descends more steeply than it ascends, and maximum height is reached before the midpoint of the range.

still symmetric with air.fix: Going up: air + gravity oppose. Going down: air opposes gravity. Different!
still symmetric with air.action: Draw both paths: ideal (symmetric parabola) vs real (asymmetric, steeper descent).

ascent is steeper.error: Descent is steeper because horizontal velocity has decreased.
ascent is steeper.fix: By the time it descends, v_x is much smaller, so it falls more steeply.
ascent is steeper.action: Slower horizontal motion + gravity = steeper fall.

maximum height at midpoint of range.error: With air, max height occurs before the midpoint.
maximum height at midpoint of range.fix: The projectile spends more distance falling than rising.
maximum height at midpoint of range.action: The horizontal distance before peak < horizontal distance after peak.

air resistance increases range.fix: Both reduced v_x and reduced time in air → much less range.
air resistance increases range.action: Golf balls go farther without air resistance (except for Magnus effect).

persistent.gap: You don't understand how air resistance changes the trajectory shape.
persistent.action: With air: steeper descent, shorter range, max height before midpoint, asymmetric.

fundamentals.title: Projectile Motion Fundamentals
fundamentals.instructions: Complete the statements about the basics of projectile motion.

sentences.text: A projectile is an object that has been launched or dropped and moves under the influence of {{d1}} alone. The path of a projectile (ignoring air resistance) is a {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the only force acting on a projectile (ignoring air)?

d2.tooltip: The curved path traced by projectiles.

sentences.text: The horizontal and vertical components of projectile motion are {{d3}}. The only variable that links them is {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Does horizontal motion affect vertical? Or vice versa?

d4.tooltip: What is the same for both horizontal and vertical motion?

sentences.text: To analyse projectile motion, we resolve the initial velocity into a {{d5}} component (v cos θ) and a {{d6}} component (v sin θ).

d5.tooltip: Cosine of the angle gives which component?

d6.tooltip: Sine of the angle gives which component?

vertical.title: Vertical Motion of Projectiles
vertical.instructions: Complete the statements about vertical projectile motion.

sentences.text: The vertical acceleration of all projectiles near Earth's surface is {{d1}}, directed {{d2}}. This is true regardless of the projectile's mass.

d1.tooltip: The value of gravitational acceleration near Earth.

sentences.text: At the maximum height of a projectile's path, the vertical velocity equals {{d3}}, but the acceleration is {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The projectile momentarily stops moving vertically at peak.

sentences.text: The vertical motion of a projectile can be analysed using the {{d5}} equations because the acceleration is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What type of motion has constant acceleration?

d6.tooltip: g = 9.8 m/s² doesn't change during flight.

horizontal.title: Horizontal Motion of Projectiles
horizontal.instructions: Complete the statements about horizontal projectile motion.

sentences.text: When air resistance is ignored, the horizontal velocity of a projectile is {{d1}} throughout its flight because there is {{d2}} acting horizontally.

d1.tooltip: Does anything slow the projectile horizontally (no air)?

d2.tooltip: Gravity acts vertically. What acts horizontally?

sentences.text: The horizontal distance travelled by a projectile is called the {{d3}}. It is calculated using the formula {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The term for horizontal distance of a projectile.

sentences.text: If a ball is thrown horizontally from a height, it takes the {{d5}} time to hit the ground as a ball dropped from the same height, because horizontal velocity does not affect {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does horizontal speed affect falling time?

air_resistance.title: Effects of Air Resistance
air_resistance.instructions: Complete the statements about air resistance effects on projectiles.

sentences.text: Air resistance is a force that {{d1}} the motion of a projectile. It acts in the {{d2}} direction to the velocity.

d1.tooltip: Does air resistance help or hinder motion?

sentences.text: With air resistance, the maximum height of a projectile is {{d3}} and the range is {{d4}} compared to the ideal case.

d3.tooltip: Air slows the projectile going up.

sentences.text: With air resistance, the trajectory becomes {{d5}}, with the descent being {{d6}} than the ascent.

d5.tooltip: Is the path the same going up and coming down?

d6.tooltip: Horizontal velocity has decreased by the time it falls.

fundamentals.title: Applying Projectile Motion Concepts
fundamentals.instructions: Apply your understanding of projectile motion fundamentals.

sentences.text: A ball thrown at 20 m/s at 30° above horizontal has initial components: v_x = 20 × cos(30°) = {{d1}} m/s and v_y = 20 × sin(30°) = {{d2}} m/s.
For a projectile launched at angle θ, the range formula R = (u² sin 2θ)/g shows that maximum range occurs at {{d3}}° because sin(2θ) is maximum when 2θ = {{d4}}°.
Two balls launched at the same speed but at complementary angles (e.g., 30° and 60°) will have {{d5}} range but {{d6}} maximum heights and flight times.

d6.tooltip: Higher angle = more time up, more height.

sentences.text: A ball thrown upward at 20 m/s reaches its peak when v_y = 0. Using v = u + at: 0 = 20 + (−9.8)t, so time to peak = {{d1}} s.
The maximum height is found using v² = u² + 2as: 0 = 20² + 2(−9.8)s, giving s = {{d2}} m.
For a projectile returning to its launch height, the total time of flight equals {{d3}} the time to reach maximum height. The landing speed equals the {{d4}} speed.

d3.tooltip: Symmetric flight: time up = time down.

d4.tooltip: Energy is conserved; same height = same speed.

sentences.text: A ball dropped from 45 m takes time t where 45 = ½(9.8)t². Solving: t = {{d5}} s.
At maximum height, the horizontal velocity is {{d6}} while the vertical velocity is zero. The total velocity at that point equals the {{d7}} component only.

d6.tooltip: Horizontal velocity never changes (no air resistance).

d7.tooltip: v_y = 0 at peak, so v = v_x.

sentences.text: A ball thrown horizontally at 15 m/s from a 20 m cliff stays in the air for 2 s. The range is {{d1}} m. The horizontal velocity when it lands is {{d2}} m/s.

d2.tooltip: Horizontal velocity stays constant (no air resistance).

sentences.text: When a package is dropped from a plane flying horizontally at 50 m/s, the package's horizontal velocity immediately after release is {{d3}} m/s. The package lands {{d4}} the plane.

d3.tooltip: Package keeps the plane's horizontal velocity.

d4.tooltip: Both plane and package have same v_x (no air resistance).

sentences.text: To find where a projectile lands, first calculate {{d5}} from vertical motion, then use this in the {{d6}} calculation.

d5.tooltip: Time links vertical and horizontal calculations.

air_resistance.title: Analysing Air Resistance Effects
air_resistance.instructions: Analyse how air resistance affects projectile motion.

sentences.text: A football kicked without air resistance would travel 60 m. With air resistance, the actual range would be {{d1}} than 60 m and the landing spot would be {{d2}} the peak.

d2.tooltip: Descent is steeper, so it falls more steeply.

sentences.text: Air resistance affects the horizontal velocity by {{d3}} it. This happens because air pushes {{d4}} on objects moving through it.

d3.tooltip: Air resistance opposes motion, slowing v_x.

d4.tooltip: Air resistance opposes the direction of motion.

sentences.text: On the way up, a projectile experiences air resistance {{d5}} gravity. On the way down, air resistance acts {{d6}} gravity.

d5.tooltip: Going up: both air and gravity push down.

d6.tooltip: Coming down: gravity pulls down, air pushes up.

fundamentals.title: Mastering Projectile Motion
fundamentals.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of projectile motion concepts.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that a ball moving upward has an upward force on it. In reality, the only force is {{d1}}, which always points {{d2}}, even when the ball is moving up.

d1.tooltip: After leaving the hand, only gravity acts.

d2.tooltip: Gravity always pulls toward Earth's centre.

sentences.text: The independence of horizontal and vertical motion can be demonstrated by {{d3}} two balls simultaneously from the same height. They hit the ground at {{d4}} time(s).

d3.correct: dropping one and throwing another horizontally
d3.tooltip: One has v_x = 0, one has v_x ≠ 0.

d4.tooltip: Same vertical motion = same time to fall.

sentences.text: At any point in a projectile's flight, the resultant velocity can be found using {{d5}}, and the angle to horizontal can be found using {{d6}}.

vertical.title: Mastering Vertical Motion Analysis
vertical.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of vertical motion calculations.

sentences.text: For a projectile launched from ground level, if you know the initial vertical velocity u_y, the maximum height can be calculated using s = {{d1}} because at maximum height, {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: The vertical velocity is zero at the peak.

sentences.text: A projectile is launched at 30 m/s at 60°. The vertical component is 30 × sin(60°) = {{d3}} m/s. Time to peak = {{d4}} s.
The sign convention matters. If upward is positive, then a = {{d5}} m/s² and a ball thrown up starts with u_y that is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Gravity acts downward = negative if up is positive.

d6.tooltip: Upward velocity is positive if up is positive.

horizontal.title: Mastering Horizontal Motion Analysis
horizontal.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of horizontal motion calculations.

sentences.text: A key insight: the time of flight is determined entirely by {{d1}} motion. Horizontal velocity only affects {{d2}}, not how long the projectile stays in the air.

d1.tooltip: Vertical motion determines when it hits ground.

d2.tooltip: More v_x means more range, not more time.

sentences.text: An arrow shot horizontally at 60 m/s from a 20 m cliff: the fall time is {{d3}} s (from s = ½gt²). The range is {{d4}} m.
When calculating final velocity of a projectile, the horizontal component is {{d5}} and the vertical component must be {{d6}}.

air_resistance.title: Mastering Air Resistance Analysis
air_resistance.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of air resistance effects.

sentences.text: VCE Physics requires {{d1}} understanding of air resistance effects. You should be able to describe how air resistance changes the trajectory but are {{d2}} to calculate it exactly.

d2.tooltip: Air resistance calculations are beyond VCE scope.

sentences.text: With air resistance, the optimal launch angle for maximum range shifts from 45° to an angle {{d3}} than 45° because the projectile spends {{d4}} time slowing down at higher altitudes.

d3.tooltip: Lower angle means less time in the air (where air slows it).

d4.tooltip: Less time in air = less energy lost to air resistance.

sentences.text: The key qualitative effects of air resistance are: reduced {{d5}}, reduced {{d6}}, asymmetric trajectory, and the projectile landing at a steeper angle than launch.

d6.tooltip: Both reduced v_x and reduced time mean less range.
